journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Effects of shear stiffness in top foil structure on gas foil bearing performance based on thick plate theory

article-meta.aff: School of Energy Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Fangcheng Xu, School of Energy Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, No. 92, West Da-Zhi Street, Harbin, Heilongjiang 150001, People’s Republic of China. Email: fcc1985@163.com

abstract.p: The effects of top foil shear stiffness for an incompressible journal foil bearing are discussed based on thick plate theory of top foil. The structural model includes bending, shear of thick plate and elastic foundation effects of bump foil. By employing the finite element method and the finite difference method, the compressible gas lubricated Reynolds equation and the film thickness equation are solved coupled together. The static characteristics such as film thickness and attitude angle are obtained and compared with literature results to verify the validation of the proposed method. Then the numerical results of thick plate model are compared with Kirchhoff plate model to study the shear stiffness effects in top foil structure on bearing performance. Results demonstrate that shear stiffness effects are significant in an elastically supported foil bearing and the shear effects should be considered in the estabilishment of 2D plate top foil model.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Bump-type foil bearings are compliant, self-acting hydro-dynamic air bearings, which are used in high-speed rotating machinery such as turbo expander, etc.1 Compared with oil bearings and rolling element bearings, these bearings have excellent reliability, environment durability and can be operated at high speeds and temperatures.2 Moreover, the foil bearings have less environmental pollution because the lubricate media is gas. The main process of predicting bump-type foil bearings is modeling the foil structure and solving compressible gas lubricated Reynolds equation coupled with the compliant surface.

Blok and van Rossum3 did analytical work in foil bearing analysis and design in the early 1950s, but only in the last two decades the interest in this type of bearing has increased considerably. In 1975 Wallowit and Anno4 first gave the theoretical model of a single bump static stiffness equation using mechanical beam model. In this bump static stiffness model, the two ends of bump were fixed and the friction between the bump foil and top foil were not considered. This bump static stiffness equation was used by Heshmat et al.5,6 to analysis gas lubricated foil journal bearing and gas lubricated compliant thrust bearing. Some other authors established finite element models of bump foil and top foil to predict hydrodynamic performance of foil journal bearings. San Andrés and Kim7 analyzed gas foil bearings integrating finite element top foil models. They used more complex finite element (FE) models coupled the elastic deformations of the 2D shell and 1D beam-like top foil to the bump deflections as well as to the gas film hydrodynamics. The results of predictions like journal attitude angle and minimum film thickness were compared with a gas foil bearing experiment data decades ago. Carpino and Talmage8 presented a fully finite element model including moment, tension, curvature and strain of foil structure, and used Newton–Raphson method to solve resulting system of nonlinear finite elements. Carpino et al.9 established a 3D model to study the effects of menbrane stresses on performance of foil bearing by using finite element method.

In this article, the role of shear stiffness in top foil structure on bearing performance was discussed based on thick plate theory. Thick plate model and Kirchhoff plate model of top foil are established, the finite element method and finite difference method are coupled together to solve Reynolds equation and foil structural deflections. Minimum film thicknesses along bearing length direction and film thickness in circumferential direction at bearing mid-plan of these two models are compared. The results indicate that the shear stiffness prevents axials and circumferential variations in gas film thickness. Menawhile, the shear effects are necessary in modeling 2D foil structual models for journal bearing.

sec.title: Bump-type foil bearing structure description
sec.p:
The structure of the first generation bump foil bearing is shown in Figure 1. It consists of a thin top foil bump and a series of corrugated bump strip layer which depicted in Figure 2. The leading edges of both bump and top foil are spot welded to the bearing sleeve, the trailing edges of foils are free. The bump foils act like springs. As the shaft rotates, the top foil would deflect when air pressure forces act on its smooth surface. Figure 1.
Structure of first generation bump foil bearing.
Figure 2.
Configuration of bump foil.
In 2D coordinates, the continuity equation and Navier–Stokes equations can be written as (1)∂u∂x+∂w∂z=0 (2)ρ(u∂u∂x+w∂u∂z)=-∂p∂x+μ(∂2u∂x2+∂2u∂z2) (3)ρ(u∂w∂x+w∂w∂z)=-∂p∂z+μ(∂2w∂x2+∂2w∂z2)

To make the analysisi of fluid film bearings with thin-film situation relatively simple, Reynolds based his theory of lubrication and derived Reynolds equation from Navier–Stokes equation by using some assumptions (Reynolds, 1886). In gas foil bearings, the bearing radial clearance h is far small than oil lubricated journal bearing, so it is feasible to use Reynolds equation to make analysis. Some scholars have proved that the differences in load-carrying capacity for solution of Navier–Stokes equations and Reynolds equation are small.10 There are some assumptions made to simplify the description of this complex flow:
The change of pressure in the direction of air film thickness is negligible since the air gap can be considered to be long and slender.
The inertia effects of gas in the slender gap are neglected.
The velocity of air at bearing sleeve surface is zero, and the velocity at shaft surface is Rω.
The fluid can be treated as an ideal gas.
The fluid flow is isothermal.
Under these simplifying assumptions the Reynolds equation for isothermal compressible fluid can be expressed as follows (4)∂∂x(ph3η∂p∂x)+∂∂z(ph3η∂p∂z)=6ω∂∂x(ph)
Dimensionless parameters are defined as follows (5)x¯=x0.5L,z¯=z0.5L,p¯=ppa,h¯=hC
Substituting equation (5) into Reynolds equation (4), the dimensionless form of the Reynolds equation is given by (6)∂∂x¯(h¯3∂p¯2∂x¯)+∂∂z¯(h¯3∂p¯2∂z¯)=Λx∂∂x¯(p¯h¯) where Λx=6RωηLpaC2

The film thickness (h) for the foil bearing is (7)h=C+ecos(θ-ϕ)+wd where C and e are the radial clearance and journal eccentricity, ϕ is the attitude angle. wd is the deflection of the support structure.

sec.title: Foil structure model
sec.p:
The finite element method is uesd to calculate the deflection of the foil structure. The top foil is modeled as a 2D plate using Kirchhoff’s thin plate theory and thick plate theory. The bending and shear deformation of the top foil are coupled in the thick plate model. The implementation of foil structure is shown in Figure 3. The bump foil is considered as linear spring and the bump structual stiffness per unit area is estimated according to the geometrical values of bump foil. Figure 3.
2D structure model of first generation bump foil bearing.

sec.title: Kirchhoff plate element
sec.p: For the Kirchhoff plate theory, the governing equation for derermining the transverse w (in the z direction) is (8)D∂4w'∂x'4+2D∂4w'∂x'2∂y'2+D∂4w'∂y'4=q'

The rectangular elastic plate element is shown in Figure 4. The stiffness matrix [ke]K of top foil element is derived by using virtual work and is shown in the Appendix 2. Figure 4.
Sketch of the rectangular plate element.

sec.title: Thick plate element
sec.p: As in the case of thick plate, the shear deformation and rotary inertial effects must be included. The relationships between the transverse shear strains γxz,γyz and the displacements are (9)γxz=∂u∂z+∂w∂x,γyz=∂v∂z+∂w∂y

The energy expressions for a thick plate are (10)Ue=12∫Aρh312{χ}T[D]{χ}dA+12∫Aκh{γ}T[Ds]{γ}dA where (11)[D]=[E(1-v2)Ev(1-v2)0E(1-v2)0SymE2(1-v)],[Ds]=E2(1+v)[1001]{χ}=[-∂θy/∂x∂θx/∂y∂θx/∂y-∂θy/∂x], {γ}=[θy+∂w/∂x-θx+∂w/∂y]

E in matirx [D] and [Ds] is plate material Young’s modulus, v is Poisson’s ratio. In an element, the transverse displacement can be expressed by combination of the nodal displacement values and shape functions (12)[wθxθy]=[N]{w}e where (13){w}eT={w1θx1θy1…w4θx4θy4} and (14)[N]=[N100…N4000N10…0N4000N1…00N4]
Substituting (14) into (10) and (11) gives (15)Ue=12{w}eT(∫Ah312[Bf]T[D][Bf]dA){w}e +12{w}eT(∫Aκh[Bs]T[D][Bs]dA){w}e
The strain matrix [Bf] is of the form (16)[Bf]=[B1f B2f B3f B4f] where (17)Bjf=[00-∂Nj/∂x0∂Nj/∂y00∂Nj/∂x-∂Nj/∂y]
The strain matrix [Bs] is of the form (18)[Bs]=[B1s B2s B3s B4s] where (19)Bjs=[∂Nj/∂x0Nj∂Nj/∂y-Nj0]

Substituting (17) and (19) into (16) and (18) and the resulting matrices into (12) renders (20)Ue=12{w}eT[k]e{w}e where the stiffness matrix [k]e is of the form (21)[ke]T=[kf]+[ks] where (22)[kf]=∫Ah312[Bf]T[D][Bf]dA and (23)[ks]=∫Aκh[Bs]T[D][Bs]dA where [kf] and [ks] are the stiffness matrices due to flexure and shear respectively and shown in Appendix 2. Petyrt11 details the derivation of stiffness matrix. The transverse displacement of plate node is equal to top foil deflection (24)w=wd

The top foil model stiffness matrix [KT] can be obtained by adding the plate element stiffness matrices one by one. Meanwhile, the bump foil stiffness matrix [KB] is derived from the single bump stiffness using different equation,12 KFF and KFW are the stiffness for a free–free ends bump and a fixed–free end bump, respectively. The stiffness matrix of total model [KG] can be obtained by adding the bump foil stiffness matrix [KB] to the top foil model stiffness matrix [KT], the express is written as follows (25)[KG]=[KT]+[KB]

For the top foil fixed end is welded, w=θx=θy=0 where w is the top foil deflection in z direction, θxis the rotation angle about x axis and θy is the rotation angle about y axis. The equation for deflections of total model is given by (26)[KG]{UG}={FG} where {UG} is the vector of displacement and {FG} is the vector of pressures acting on the top foil. The expressions of {UG} and {FG} are written as follows (27){UG}={w1θx1θy1w2θx2θx2……}T (28){FG}={p100p200……}T where p1, p2 … are the pressures acting on the top foil element nodes.
The finite element analysis is taken before solving the thin gas film governed by Reynolds equation (6) and its results w is used for equation (7) to update the film thickness.

sec.title: Solution with Newton–Raphson method
sec.p: Newton–Raphson iteration of function F(p¯) is written as follows (29)F(p¯n)+F'(p¯n)δ=0 where δ=p¯n+1-p¯n+1,n=0,1,2,…,
Expanding function F(p¯+βδ) in the form of a Taylor series about p¯, and do the first derivative with respect to β, the approximate expression form is obtained (30)dF(p¯+βδ)dβ|β=0=δF'(p¯)=-F(p¯)

Substituting equation (30) into Reynolds equation (6) and settingβ=0, yields (31) 2[∂∂x¯(h¯3δ∂p¯∂x¯+h¯3p¯∂δ∂x¯)]+2[∂∂z¯(h¯3δ∂p¯∂z¯+h¯3p¯∂δ∂z¯)] -Λx(h¯∂δ∂x¯+δ∂h¯∂x¯) -[∂∂x¯(h¯3∂p¯2∂θ)+∂∂z¯(h¯3∂p¯2∂z¯)-Λx∂(p¯h¯)∂x¯]

The expanded form of the left-hand side (LEFT) and the right-hand side (RIGHT) of equation (31) are (32)LEFT=δ(3h¯2∂h¯∂x¯∂p¯∂x¯+h¯3∂2p¯∂x¯2+3h¯2∂h¯∂z¯∂p¯∂z¯+h¯3∂2p¯∂z¯2) +∂δ∂x¯(2h¯3∂p¯∂x¯+3h¯2p¯∂h¯∂x¯)+∂δ∂z¯(2h¯3∂p¯∂z¯+3h¯2p¯∂h¯∂z¯) +h¯3p¯(∂2δ∂x¯2+∂2δ∂z¯2)-Λx2(δ∂h¯∂x¯+h¯∂δ∂x¯) (33)RIGHT=-h¯3[(∂p¯∂x¯)2+(∂p¯∂z¯)2]-h¯3p¯(∂2p¯∂x¯2+∂2p¯∂z¯2) -3h¯2p¯(∂h¯∂x¯∂p¯∂x¯+∂h¯∂z¯∂p¯∂z¯)+Λx2(h¯∂p¯∂x¯+p¯∂h¯∂x¯)

The finite different form of the LEFT and the RIGHT of equation (31) can be expressed by the following coefficient matrices (34)ai,jδi-1,j+bi,jδi+1,j+ci,jδi,j+di,jδi,j-1+ei,jδi,j+1=-si,j (35)ai,j=-h¯i,j3(p¯i+1,j-p¯i-1,j)2Δx¯2-3h¯i,j2p¯i,j(h¯i+1,j-h¯i-1,j)4Δx¯2 +Λxh¯i,j4Δx¯+h¯i,j3p¯i,jΔx¯2 (36)bi,j=h¯i,j3(p¯i+1,j-p¯i-1,j)2Δx¯2+3h¯i,j2p¯i,j(h¯i+1,j-h¯i-1,j)4Δx¯2 -Λxh¯i,j4Δx¯+h¯i,j3p¯i,jΔx¯2 (37)ci,j=3h¯i,j2(h¯i+1,j-h¯i-1,j)(p¯i+1,j-p¯i-1,j)4Δx¯2 +h¯i,j3(p¯i+1,j-2p¯i,j+p¯i-1,j)Δx¯2 +3h¯i,j2(h¯i,j+1-h¯i,j-1)(p¯i,j+1-p¯i,j-1)4Δz¯2 +h¯i,j3(p¯i,j+1-2p¯i,j+p¯i,j-1)Δz¯2 -2h¯i,j3p¯i,jΔz¯2-Λx(h¯i+1,j-h¯i-1,j)4Δx¯-2h¯i,j3p¯i,jΔx¯2 (38)di,j=-h¯i,j3(p¯i,j+1-p¯i,j-1)2Δz¯2-3h¯i,j2p¯i,j(h¯i,j+1-h¯i,j-1)4Δz¯2 +h¯i,j3p¯i,jΔz¯2 (39)ei,j=h¯i,j3(p¯i,j+1-p¯i,j-1)2Δz¯2+3h¯i,j2p¯i,j(h¯i,j+1-h¯i,j-1)4Δz¯2 +4h¯i,j3p¯i,jΔz¯2 (40)si,j=h¯i,j3[(p¯i+1,j-p¯i-1,j2Δx¯)2+(p¯i,j+1-p¯i,j-12Δz¯)2]+p¯i,jh¯i,j3· [p¯i+1,j-2p¯i,j+p¯i-1,jΔx¯2+p¯i,j+1-2p¯i,j+p¯i,j+1Δz¯2]+3p¯i,jh¯i,j2· [h¯i+1,j-h¯i-1,j2Δx¯·p¯i+1,j-p¯i-1,j2Δx¯+h¯i,j+1-h¯i,j-12Δz¯·p¯i,j+1-p¯i,j-12Δz¯] -Λx2[h¯i,jp¯i+1,j-p¯i-1,j2Δx¯+p¯i,jh¯i+1,j-h¯i-1,j2Δx¯]

The rigid schematic of shaft journal surface is displayed in Figure 5. Because film thickness and pressure distribution of gas foil bearing are symmetrical about the mid-plane in bearing length direction, only half side of the bearing is considered for analysis (from z = 0 to z = L/2). In circumferential direction (i.e. coordinate ‘x’), the length is averaged by ‘nx’. In the bearing length direction (i.e. coordinate z’), the half length of bearing is averaged by ‘nz’ In the end, there are ‘nz + 1’ nodes in half of shaft length, and ‘nx + 1’ nodes in whole circumferential length. The solved range is defined as (1: nx + 1, 1: nz + 1). Figure 5.
Grid schematic diagram of the computational area.

There are two kinds of boundary conditions in solution of Reynolds equation.
The atmosphere boundary condition: p¯(1:nx+1,0)=1p¯(1,0:nz+1)=p¯(nx+1,0:nz+1)=1
The symmetrical boundary condition: p¯(1:nx+1,nz-1)=p¯(1:nx+1,nz+1)∂p¯i,j∂z¯=0(i=1:nx+1,j=nz)

Meanwhile, the boundary conditions for solution of foil structure deflection are:
The fixed boundary condition: w,θx,θy(1,0:nz+1)=0
The symmetrical boundary condition: θy(1:nx+1,nz)=0
The film thickness and pressure distribution are obtained from iterative calculation. The convergence condition is given by (41)∑i=1nx∑j=1nz(Δp¯i,jp¯i,j)2≤10-6 (42)∑i=1nx∑j=1nz(Δh¯i,jh¯i,j)2≤10-6

Then the dimensionless load capacity equations in two directions and the total dimensionless load capacity equation are written as follows (43)W¯x=2∫02πR∫0L/2(p¯-1)sin(xR)dxdz (44)W¯y=2∫02πR∫0L/2(p¯-1)cos(xR)dxdz (45)W¯=(W¯x)2+(W¯y)2
The total load capacity and the attitude angle are (46)W=W¯×p0,ϕ=arctan(-Wx¯Wy¯)

In the total process of calculation, an arbitrary initial pressure distribution is applied to obtain foil structure deflections using equation (26). Then the deflections values are used to calculate the film thickness (h) equation (4), and the new pressure distribution is calculated by substituting film thickness values into the solution of Reynolds equation. At last, a final iteration loop is added to make sure the balance of rotor and the attitude angle is converged. The numerical procedure is illustrated in Figure 6. The iteration procedure for solution of Reynolds equation is finished when relative differences both of air pressure and gas film thickness is less than 1 × 10−6. The boundary conditions and process of calculation is similar in mind to literature.13–15 Figure 6.
Overall analysis flowchart.

sec.title: Configuration of gas foil bearing
sec.p:
The analysis results of foil bearing models are compared with literature results to verify its validity. The literature results quoted in this paper is for 1D beam model and 2D plate model with anisotropic property shear effect. The parameters for simulation are from Kim and San Andrés16 and Kumar and Kim17 and summarized in Table 1. The top foil and bump foil are spot-welded together at one end to the bearing house. The other ends of top foil and bump foil are both free. The bump foil stiffness per unit area (Kf) is: Kff = 4.7 × 109 N/m3, Kfw = 10.4 × 109 N/m3 corresponding to free–free ends bump and fixed–free end bump, respectively. Table 1.
Data used in simulations.
Foil bearing parameters
Bearing diameter (2 R) 38.1 × 10−3 m
Bearing length (L) 38.1 × 10−3 m
Diametral clearance (2C) 63.6 × 10−6 m
Top foil thickness (tT) 101.6 × 10−6 m
Bump foil thickness (tB) 101.6 × 10−6 m
Bump foil Young’s modulus (EB) 214 × 109 Pa
Bump length (2 l) 3.556 × 10−3 m
Bump pitch (s) 4.572 × 10−3 m
Bump height (hB) 0.508 × 10−3 m
Bump foil Poisson’s ratio (vb) 0.29
Lubricant (air) data
Pressure (pa) 101,325 Pa
Viscosity (η) (at 30℃) 1.87 × 10−5 Pa s
Density (ρ0) 1.13 kg/m3

The gas foil bearing simulation using the Kirchhoff plate model and thick plate model to predict the static performance of the bearing. As the first generation bump foil bearing structure is symmetrical about the mid-plane, the results are presented for only half of the bearing. All of the models use a mesh of 78 and 10 elements in the circumferential and axial direction. So the bump stiffness for a free–free ends bump and a fixed–free end bump are KFF=Kff×Ab=40935.4N/mKFW=Kfw×Ab=90580.5N/m

Here the elastic modulus for the top foil is artificially increased, ET = EB × Sfc, where Sfc is a stiffening factor along the circumferential direction, EB and ET are the elastic modulus for the bump foil and top foil, respectively. In San Andrés and Kim,7 Sfc = 4, so the modulus of top foil is ET = 856 GPa.

sec.title: Minimum film thickness and journal attitude angle
sec.p:
Figure 7 presents the minimum film thickness versus static load for operation at shaft speed: (a) 30,000 r/min and (b) 45,000 r/min, respectively. The figure is comprised of predictions for two foil bearing models and literature results which used 1D beam model and 2D plate model with anisotropic property shear effect.7 The simulation data are all at the bearing edge. Under the same static load condition, the predictions of thick plate model is similar to 1D beam model, but they are both bigger than 2D FE model results in San Andrés and Kim.7 The curve of Kirchhoff plate model prediction declines dramatically with increasing of static load. Needs to be pointed out is: for the Kirchhoff plate model, when the static load reach 33.7 N at 30,000 r/min and 39.3 N at 45,000 r/min respectively, the minimum film thickness are both equal to zero, that means the top foil at bearing edge contacts to the shaft due to the absence of shear force which can pull back top foil at the bearing edge. Figure 7.
Minimum film thickness at bearing edge versus static load for two foil structure models and literature results7 at two shaft speeds.

Figure 8 presents the minimum film thickness versus static load for operation at the bearing mid-plane. The shaft speed is 30,000 r/min and 45,000 r/min, respectively. Under the same static load condition, the predictions of thick plate model are almost the same with 1D beam model when the static load is heavy enough. This behavior may be due to axially average pressure acted on 1D beam model. Both the Kirchhoff plate model and 2D FE model in San Andrés and Kim7 overestimate the film thickness when compared to thick plate model. The predictions difference between thick plate model and 2D FE model in San Andrés and Kim7 may be due to the process of pressure along bearing edge. In San Andrés and Kim,7 foil deflections along its edge are calculated using the axial upstream pressures modified by the local Peclet number,18 but in this article, the pressures at bearing edge are equal to ambient pressure. Figure 8.
Minimum film thickness at mid-plane versus static load for two foil structure models and literature results7 at two shaft speeds.

Figure 9 shows the journal attitude angle versus static load at shaft speed: (a) 30,000 r/min and (b) 45,000 r/min. The figure includes predictions of two foil bearing models and literature results in San Andrés and Kim.7 The numerical results of thick plate model is far small than 1D beam model, especially at high static load level. Since the top foil will contact to shaft surface, the Kirchhoff plate model can only have limited values at low static load level. Figure 9.
Journal attitude angle versus static load for two foil structure models and literature results7 at two shaft speeds.
Here should be pointed out that the Reynolds number of gas foil bearing operating at speed of 45,000 r/min is about 172, far below the critical value of ReCR ≈ 500–800. The flow remains laminar.19

sec.title: Air pressure distribution and gas film thickness
sec.p:
The predicted dimensionless pressure distribution (p/pa) is depicted in Figure 10. The static load is 33.7 N and the shaft speed is 30,000 r/min. The gas film thickness corresponding to this pressure distribution for Kirchhoff plate model and thick plate model are depicted in Figures 11 and 12, respectively. In all the three figures, the pressure and film thickness are plotted for the symmetric half of the bearing. From bearing mid-plane to edge, the gas film thickness of Kirchhoff plate model decreases dramatically to zero while remains almost constant for thick plate model. This discrepancy is due to shear effect of plate element. Figure 10.
Predicted dimensionless pressure distribution. Static load: 33.7 N, shaft speed: 30 kr/min.
Figure 11.
Gas film thickness for Kirchhoff plate model. Static load: 33.7 N, shaft speed: 30 kr/min.
Figure 12.
Gas film thickness for thick plate model. Static load: 33.7 N, shaft speed: 30 kr/min.

The effects of stiffness due to shear on gas film thickness are further demonstrated by the results in Figures 13 and 14. In both figures, the film thickness at point of minimum film thickness along bearing length direction for two plate models is plotted for half of bearing with different values of static loads. Since the pressure in the gas film decreases from bearing mid-plane to edge, both of the two models’ film thickness also decrease along with it. If the eccentricity and static load are increased, the minimun gas film thickness at bearing edge for two models will became small. However, the absences of shear stiffness for Kirchhoff plate model lead a sharp fall of film thickness curves from bearing mid-plane to edge and the film thickness even equals to zero when static load is 33.7 N. Meanwhile the shear effect of thick plate model can hold the top foil deflection along bearing length direction and even when static load up to 142.2 N, the minimum film thickness is 4.02 × 10−6 m at bearing edge. Figure 13.
Gas film thickness at point of minimum film thickness for Kirchhoff plate model at different load capacity. Speed: 30 kr/min.
Figure 14.
Gas film thickness at point of minimum film thickness for thick plate model at different load capacity. Speed: 30 kr/min.

To make a complete comparison, an additional film thickness comparison versus circumferential direction at bearing mid-plane between thick plate model and Kirchhoff plate model is plotted in Figure 15. The static load is 33.7 N, shaft speed is 30 kr/min. When under the same static load condition, the predicted film thickness of thick plate model is smaller than Kirchhoff plate model in the zone of smallest film thickness at bearing mid-plane. It means that the thick plate model has a bigger foil structure stiffness than Kirchhoff plate model due to adding shear stiffness. Moreover, the ripple shape between two adjacent bumps of Kirchhoff plate model is more obvious than thick plate model for the same reason. Figure 15.
Comparison of gas film thickness versus circumferential direction at bearing mid-plane for Kirchhoff plate model and thick plate model. Static load: 33.7 N, shaft speed: 30 kr/min.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A thick plate model for foil structure has been presented. Hydrodynamic analysis of a specific foil bearing is done using finite element method and finite difference method. The numerical results such as gas film thickness and attitude angle are compared to literature results to verify the correction of analysis approch of this model.

The effects of shear stiffness in top foil strucure on bearing performance has been studied by comparing predictions of thick plate model with Kirchhoff plate model. The results indicate that shear effects are necessary in modeling 2D foil structual models for journal bearing. Kirchhoff plate model is less precise than thick plate model. Even under low static load condition, the top foil will would contact to the journal surface in the absence of the gas film pressure at bearing dege without shear forces in the top foil, which will not happen in actual condition. Through the film thickness along axial and circumferential direction comparison of the two models, it shows that has a bigger foil structure stiffness than Kirchhoff plate model due to adding shear stiffness. In addition, the shear stiffness prevents axial and circumferential variations in gas film thickness.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant no. 11176010) and by the Aeronautical Science Foundation of China (Grant no. 20110377005). The authors are greatful for their supports.

ref.citation: Agrawal G. Foil air/gas bearing technology - an overview. ASME paper 97-GT-347, 1997.
FengKKanekoS. Analytical model of bump-type foil bearings using a link-spring structure and a finite-element shell model. ASME J Tribol 2010; 132: 021706–021706.
BlokHvan RossumJJ. The foil bearing-a new departure in hydrodynamic lubrication. Lubric Eng 1953; 9(6): 316–320.
WalowitJAAnnoJN. Modern developments in lubrication mechanics, London: Applied Science Publishers Ltd, 1975.
HeshmatHWalowitJAPinkusO. Analysis of gas-lubricated foil journal bearings. ASME J Lubric Technol 1983; 105: 647–655.
HeshmatHWalowitJAPinkusO. Analysis of gas-lubricated complaint thrust bearings. Trans ASME 1983; 105: 638–646.
San Andrés L and Kim TH. Improvements to the analysis of gas foil bearings integrating of top foil 1D and 2D structural models. ASME paper GT2007-27249, 2007.
CarpinoMTalmageG. A fully coupled finite element formulation for elastically supported foil journal bearing. Tribol Trans 2003; 46(4): 560–565.

sec.title: Thick rectangular element
sec.p: The stiffness matrix [ke]T is of the form (49)[ke]T=[kf]+[ks]

The remaining sub-matrices of (50) are given by relationships corresponding to the following forms (52)k22f=I3Tk11fI3k32f=I3Tk41fI3,k33f=I1Tk11fI1k42f=I3Tk31fI3,k43f=I1Tk21fI1,k44f=I2Tk11fI2 where (53)I1=[-100010001],I2=[1000-10001],I3=[10001000-1]

The stiffness matrix due to shear is of the form (54)[ks]=Eh348abβs[k11sSymk21sk22sk31sk32sk33sk41sk42sk43sk44s] where βs=Eh2/12κGb2 is a shear parameter, also k11s=[(1+α2)α2b-aα2bα2b20-a0a2] (55)k21s=[(-1+α2)α2baα2bα2b20-a0a2]k31s=[(-1-α2)-α2baα2bα2b0-a0a2]k41s=[(1-α2)-α2b-aα2bα2b20-a0a2]

The remaining sub-matrices of (54) are given by relationships corresponding to the following forms (56)k22s=I3Tk11sI3k32s=I3Tk41sI3,k33s=I1Tk11sI1k42s=I3Tk31sI3,k43s=I1Tk21sI1,k44s=I2Tk11sI2 where (57)I1=[-100010001],I2=[1000-10001],I3=[10001000-1] and

a is the half length of plate element (m), b, the half width of plate element (m), h, the thickness of plate element (m), ν, the plate element Poisson’s ratio (–), E, the Young’s modulus (Pa), G, the shear modulus (Pa) and κ, the shear coefficient.
